title: Grace Dieu Priory Woods Walk Route

images.title: Trevor Rickard / Grace Dieu Priory - 1
images.caption: Grace Dieu Priory. Looking east from the A512. Although the area around Grace Dieu has historical connections dating back to the Romans and beyond, the Priory came into being around 1235-1241 as a house for Augustinian canonesses. The priory was dissolved in 1538 by Henry VIII.

images.title: Old canal bed at Grace Dieu Priory by Ian Calderwood, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Old canal bed at Grace Dieu Priory

images.title: michael szebor / Spring In Grace Dieu Wood
images.caption: Spring In Grace Dieu Wood. A carpet of Wood Anemone's in this beautiful section of wet woodland.

images.title: Richard Croft / Grace Dieu bridge
images.caption: Grace Dieu bridge. Disused railway bridge of the Coalville to Loughborough Railway Line in the woods.

images.title: Richard Croft / Grace Dieu Wood
images.caption: Clearing in the woods in spring.

images.title: Richard Croft / Rusty Mary
images.caption: Rusty Mary. Sculpture by Mike Evens also known as the Iron Madonna, located near the ruins at the site.

images.title: Ralph Rawlinson / Grace Dieu Viaduct, Thringstone, Leicestershire
images.caption: Grace Dieu Viaduct. This disused viaduct was on Charnwood Forest Railway three miles north of Coalville. It takes it name from the nearby, priory and brook of the same which it crossed.

images.title: michael szebor / Grace Dieu Brook
images.caption: Grace Dieu Brook. An autumn view.

description: This historic 13th century priory is located close to Coalville in North West Leicestershire. It's a pleasant place for an easy walk with the photogenic ancient ruins surrounded by some attractive woodland trails. In the woods there's views of the Grace Dieu Brook and in the spring lots of pretty Wood Anenome's can be seen too. One nice idea is to combine this walk with a visit to Mount St Bernard Abbey . The abbey lies just to the south east of the priory and can be reached by picking up the Ivanhoe Way at the southern end of the woods. Follow the waymarked trail east and it will take you past Whitwick to the abbey. Near here there's also Blackbrook Reservoir where you'll find some pleasant waterside trails to try.
